DEFAULT.question: What is the safety net on my brokerage account? What happens if Groww discontinues service??
DEFAULT.answer:
Your assets and account are held by Apex Clearing and managed by ViewTrade securities. 

In the unlikely event that Groww and ViewTrade move out of business, your holdings and account will be completely safe and kept with Apex. 

You might not be able to trade further till the time a broker is allocated, but your holdings will be untouched. 

In the event that the custodian discontinues business then the SIPC insurance of $500,000 will kick in. 

In the US, the customer's holdings/assets are kept in separate accounts and cannot be touched for business purposes or neither will it act as a collateral for company/broker firms.

DEFAULT.question: What insurance do I get for my account?
DEFAULT.answer:
US brokerage regulation recommends that every account is to be insured as per SIPC insurance act. 

Growwâ€™s brokerage partner, ViewTrade, is a member of SIPC which protects all securities and cash holdings in your accounts up to $500,000 of which $250,000 may be in cash. 

SIPC protects the customer's assets in a financially troubled SICP brokerage member firm. 

Please note that this $500,000 (USD) is not applicable on general losses in the stock market.

DEFAULT.question: What are tax implications?
DEFAULT.answer:
Taxation for US stocks is very straight forward. 

Due to the Double Taxation Avoidance Agreement (DTAA) between India and the US there is no tax on capital gains deducted in the US for Indian residents. 

You will have to pay for capital gains tax in India based upon long term (above 24 months) and short term (below 24 months) holdings of your investments.

DEFAULT.question: How will dividends be taxed?
DEFAULT.answer:
If you receive a dividend, your tax liability in the US would be a flat 25% which will be deducted at source. 

You will receive 75% of the dividend as cash payout in your brokerage account.

You will receive foreign tax credits for the US tax, which you can utilize against your tax liability in India (as the US and India have a Double Taxation Avoidance Agreement). 

You can download the statements from Groww.

DEFAULT.question: Can I take indexation benefit on transfer of foreign listed securities?
DEFAULT.answer:
Indexation benefit is given to adjust the cost of capital assets held for long term with respect to inflation. 

Since foreign securities are considered are unlisted, they must be held for at least 24 months to qualify as Long Term Capital Asset and avail indexation.

DEFAULT.question: How will the TCS provision work for international stocks?
DEFAULT.answer:
As per Finance Act, 2020, An authorized dealer (bank) receiving amounts from resident individuals has to collect 5% TCS, where the amount or the aggregate of the amount is Rs 7.0 lakh or more. 

The TCS covers all remittances made under the Liberalised Remittance Scheme (LRS) of the Reserve Bank of India (RBI). 

This TCS can be adjusted against the final tax liability of the person. 

You can get your monthly TDS reduced if it is a salaried individual or adjust against advance tax payment when the next instance falls due. 

Note: TCS provision will be applicable from October 1st 2020.
